results.title: Home
results.brief_description: As a child home was just an illusion. Growing up, moving overseas, home became temperal and Australia became “just back home” and on returning home, nothing made sense - everything had changed. Perhaps my mother’s words that “home is where the heart is” says it all.

results.title: Home
results.brief_description: Home may not be palatial but it’s where you want to be; the story of a seventy year old woman’s search for a space of her own. Cast includes Queenie Ashton, Sue Brooks, Jill Clayton and others. Director of photographer: Laurie Kirkwood; Production Manager: Sue Richter; 1st Assistant: Jane Campion; Production Assistant: Anna Grieve.

results.title: Home
results.brief_description: A doco on “home” and “homelessness” - what is a “home” and what does “homelessness” mean to those who live it? The film provides a personal insight and commentary from a cross-section of the homeless community in Melbourne along with those who are lucky enough not to have experienced the social alienation, loneliness and hardships of homelessness. Thought-provoking and experimental in its presentation, Home is beautifully produced and directed by Amanda Sykes, with stunning images by cinematographer Brett Brogan, and supported by an evocative sound design and score from Pip Atherstone-Reid.

results.title: Hombre
results.creator_credit: Martin Ritt, Irving Ravetch and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Paul Newman is the hero in this exciting, hard hitting western. John Russell is a white man raised as an Apache who faces the prejudices of a society which despises him. He is made to sit outside the stage coach by the white passengers who soon find that their lives are dependent on the man they rejected when outlaws leave them stranded in the desert. Co-starring Diane Cilento, Frederic March, Richard Boone and Barbara Rush.

results.title: Homage to Verdi
results.brief_description: Follows Sherrill Milnes as he visits Verdi’s birthplace and home in Italy, where Milnes is preparing to perform a Verdi opera.

results.title: Homage to the herbster
results.creator_credit: Leo Kane and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Sometimes he inscribes his name in wet cement. As long as he spells it correctly, I’ll let it ride. A simple tale of an intense relationship between a Big Issue vendor and his terrier, his partner in both work and life.

results.title: Homage a George Bizet
results.brief_description: Biographical account of Georges Bizet’s life supported by and illustrated with excerpts from his compositions. Particularly featured are L’Arlierienne and Carmen. In French language only.

results.title: Holzwege: wood roads/wrong ways
results.creator_credit: George Wallace-Crabbe and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Inspired by the diaries of a prisoner (in this case Nazi war criminal Albert Speer). In his daily exercise Speer began to measure the kilometres covered and projected his walk, in imaginative terms, across Southern Europe to Asia, Russia and the frozen Bering Strait. The film is constructed like a documentary of his imaginary journey. Holzwege, which translates as ‘wood road’ or ‘wrong way’ or ‘dead end’, was the pseudonym he used when signing the diaries.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Wallace-Crabbe and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School

results.title: Holy smoke
results.creator_credit: Jane Campion, Jan Chapman, Saddleback Productions and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: During a backpacking holiday in India, Ruth, a young Australian woman, experiences a spiritual awakening at an ashram. Convinced that she has found peace, harmony and purpose she decides to stay on with her newfound guru, much to the horror of her family in Australia. Luring her back to suburban Sydney on false pretences they employ the services of P.J., an American ‘cult-exiter’. The deprogramming encounter that takes place over three days in a shack on an isolated outback farm becomes a battle of wits and wills over spirituality and sexuality. Returning to the themes of dysfunctional family life that she focused on in her first feature “Sweetie”, Campion employs cultural stereotypes to contrast the exotic appeal of Eastern spiritualism for the idealistic Ruth, with her family’s lack of understanding and crassness. The film’s central concern with the search for the meaning of life is juxtaposed with comedic elements drawn from the repertoire of cliched Australian ‘types’ that were a commonplace of Australian cinema in the nineties, and moments of high melodrama. Though Campion clearly demonstrated her cinematic and technical proficiency, the narrative was considered by some critics to be somewhat clumsy and overambitious.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jane Campion, Jan Chapman, Saddleback Productions and Miramax Films

results.title: Holy She*p
results.creator_credit: Magnus Kravik, Katerina Pantela and Arts University Bournemouth
results.brief_description:
Pursued by a nun with a shearing blade, a sheep tries frantically to escape. Does the cruise ship visiting his island hold a hope of sybaritic freedom? Perhaps, but not in quite the way our protagonist dreams.
Story and animation: Parina Mehta, Katerina Pantela, Magnus Kravik
Layout, background and design: Heather Vogel, Katerina Pantela
Assistant animators: Mengly Li, Dominic Elsey
Editors: Carl Reader, Thorbjorn Munter
Music and sound design: Daniel Weismayr
